results.title: G'day: new accents in australian tourism
results.creator_credit: Anne Basser, Colin South and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changing Australia”.
Tourism is Australia’s largest employer and continues to grow in importance. This program looks at the importance of understanding the cultures our visitors come from and also at the importance of developing foreign language skills for those involved in the tourist industry. We see examples of how Australia can capitalise on the language and cultural skills which already exist within the migrant communities. The program also considers alternative types of tourism, some of which are beginning to involve Aborigines on a more active basis.

results.title: G'day sport
results.creator_credit: Peter Johnson, David Roberts and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontiers downunder”.
A slightly different look at a nation that is apparently “sports mad”. This malady and the sort of sporting competition need for most Australians is examined, as well as the extremes that people in the outback go to in order to satisfy their competitive needs

results.title: Future wave: Japan design
results.brief_description: This documentary explores, through example and personal reflection, the economics, aesthetics, personalities, and traditional spiritual links that translate so spectacularly into Japanese design.

results.title: Future urban form
results.brief_description: “Summary: attemps to describe, analyse and evaluate certain trends and future possibilities for urban form in britain. two trends are isolated upward extension outward growth. the processes that underlie these trends are the examined. the development of the lift being largely responsible for upward extension, while outward growth is largely associated with the railroad and car. the ideas of a number of visionaries are then examined”

results.title: Future shock
results.creator_credit: Metro Media Corporation and Alex Grasshoff
results.brief_description: Examines the current phenomenon of future shock, the condition which results from too much change too fast. Current technological developments are presented through interviews with scientists. The film echoes Alvin Toffler’s questioning of whether or not change is necessary, and if it is out of control.

results.title: Future looks rosy
results.brief_description: Looks at the problems of soil salinity due to erosion and poor agricultural practices. In cooperation with the Department of Conservation, Forests & Land, landholders are seeking solutions to the problem of land degradation.

results.title: Future eaters. Ep. 3: eating the future
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), North South Productions, Television New Zealand. New Zealand Natural History Unit, Ian Cuming and Richard Keefe
results.brief_description: Episode three of a provocative three part ecological history of Australasia based on Dr Tim Flannery’s best selling book of the same name. It focuses on the exploitation for food of flora and fauna resources, firstly by the indigenous populations of Australia and New Zealand and then by European colonists. This episode looks at the introduction of European farming methods and feral creatures by colonists and their catastrophic effect on our local eco systems in the form of the extinction of many native fauna and irreversible damage to much of Australia’s land. Written and presented by Dr Tim Flannery. Further information available at www.abc.net.au/science/future.

results.title: Future eaters. Ep. 2: nomads of the wind
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), North South Productions, Television New Zealand. New Zealand Natural History Unit, Ian Cuming and Richard Keefe
results.brief_description: Episode two of a provocative three part ecological history of Australasia based on Dr Tim Flannery’s best selling book of the same name. It focuses on the exploitation for food of flora and fauna resources, firstly by the indigenous populations of Australia and New Zealand and then by European colonists. This episode looks at the impact of hunting and fishing by Maori before European colonisation. The primeval forests of New Zealand were home to many unique creatures which they devoured to extinction. They also rapidly depleted marine life until they no longer had enough to eat. The result was war over resources, followed by conservation measures to preserve food sources, some of which continue to this day. Written and presented by Dr Tim Flannery. Further information available at www.abc.net.au/science/future.

results.title: Future eaters. Ep. 1: taming the fire
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), North South Productions, Television New Zealand. New Zealand Natural History Unit, Ian Cuming and Richard Keefe
results.brief_description: Episode one of a provocative three part ecological history of Australasia based on Dr Tim Flannery’s best selling book of the same name. It focuses on the exploitation for food of flora and fauna resources, firstly by the indigenous populations of Australia and New Zealand and then by European colonists. This episode looks at the reasons behind the extinction of Australia’s megafauna, the giant marsupials that roamed the continent before human habitation. Presenter Dr Tim Flannery believes that they were wiped out by the Aborigines upon their arrival in Australia 40-60,000 years ago. The extinctions were the catalyst for environmental meltdown, from which the Aborigines made a triumphant recovery. Written and presented by Dr Tim Flannery. Further information available at www.abc.net.au/science/future.
